overview.name: Chief Executive Officers
overview.description: Reed Hastings is the fifth highest paid CEO in the U.S. as of 2019 making ~39 million dollars. In 1997, Reed Hastings and Marc Randolph had an idea to rent DVDs by mail. They tested the concept by mailing themselves a DVD. The DVD arrived intact, and the idea for Netflix was born. In 2011, Hastings took heat for separating Netflix's DVD business and online streaming service, as he foresaw the downfall of DVD's. CEO Reed Hastings says “Netflix leaders hire, develop and cut smartly, so we have stars in every position”. Ted Sarandos is Chief Content Officer and was appointed Co-CEO in 2020. In 2015, he positioned Netflix to move on from a monthly DVD subscription to a full on streaming service competing with HBO and cable. He oversees an aquisition budget over $4 billion. He had a vision for the future of television made up of algorithms based on taste.

overview.name: Marketing and Communications
overview.description: Bozoma Saint John is the Chief Marketing Officer at Netflix. She has a 20 year career in marketing and has been inducted into the American Advertising Federation Hall of Acheivement. She has a Bachelors degree in English and African American Studies from Wesleyan University and now lives in Los Angeles. She was recently selected as a keynote speaker at the ON24 Experience, a national virtual marketing conference. Rachel Whetstone is the Chief Communications Officer at Netflix and specializes in communications policies for U.S. technology companies. She graduated from Bristol University in England. In The Silicon Valley Business Journal, it is explained that Rachel and a few other Netflix executives were hired from big name competitors like Netflix and Disney.

overview.name: Strategy
overview.description: Bill Holmes is the Vice President of Strategy and Partnerships. He graduated from Trinity University in Connecticut. He previously served as Global and Chief Business Development Officers. He has helped Netflix partner with large companies such as Apple, Microsoft, and Nintendo to name a few. He launched a program called "DivX Certified" for digital technology like TV's, phones and cameras. Verna Myers is the Vice President od Inclusion Strategy. Verna graduated from Columbia University magna cum laude and Harvard Law School. She is best known for being an activist, thought leader and social commentator. She has written a book on Diversity and Inclusion and has given Ted Talks on the subject. Business Insider did a piece on her and how she uses anti-racist vocabulary to successfully build equity in the workplace. Mark Yurechko is the Vice President of Strategy, Planning and Analysis. He guides key business decisions and also helps with programming analytics and competeive intellegence. He has a bachelor's degree from Duke and an MBA from UNC Chapel Hill. He worked on strategy at Deloitte for nine years as well.

overview.name: Global Relations
overview.description: Bela Bajaria is the Head of Global TV at Netflix and evaluates scripted and unscripted, English and local languages globally. She pushed for unscripted filming in "Queer Eye, Nailed It!" and "Tidying Up with Marie Kondo". She has been awarded by the "I Have a Dream" Foundation, The March of Dimes Foundation, and is named by Fortune as one of the most powerful women of 2020 and a leader in entertainment. Minyoung Kim is the Vice President of Content for Korea, Southeast Asia, Austrailia, and New Zealand. She brought the best of Korean series to global audiences on Netflix and was one of the first content executives to be based in Asia. She has helped take part in Netflix's creation of Korean original series as well as the creation of an office in Seoul, SK. She has experience in international business working for NBC in France and CJ E&M in Korea. She talks about the work she has been doing in an aticle on Netflix's website, stating that Netlix is investing 500 million USD into Korea in 2021. Francisco Ramos is the Vice President of Latin American Content and is responsible for all content liscensed within that region. He received his law degree from National Autonomous University of Mexico. He started his career in Spain in a few media corporations. Scott Stuber is the Head of Global Film and oversees production and development of Netflix films. Before Netflix he was involved in the creation of Bluegrass films. He used to be a high level executive at Universal Studios, creating well known titles like "Bourne" and "Fast and Furious" movie series. He is also active in many charity organizations. In a Wall Street Journal article, Stuber is mentioned as the head of two departments: Netflix orginals and Indies. He plans to budget Originals between 20 and 200 million for 20 movies per year. The Indies department is planning to create 35 movies per year at a lower budget of 20 million.

overview.name: Talent Management
overview.description: Jessica Neal is the Chief Talent Officer at Netflix. She has been with the company since 2006 and has been involved in influencing company culture for the best. She left in 2013 to pursue an HR career elsewhere, but returned again in 2017 to oversee the engineering team that works continuously to improve Netlix's product, or online platform. Allison Wright is the Vice President of Talent. She has a bachelors degree from San Jose State and a masters from University of San Francisco. Wright supports production, animation and HR efforts while also acting as a business partner to other Netflix executives. She has worked in HR in many other industries as well, including retail, hospitality and healthcare. She works as a Trustee for The Actor's Fund, too.

overview.name: Product and Operations Management
overview.description: Greg Peters is Chief Operating Officer and Chief Product Officer. He is head of the product team, tailoring the Netflix experience. He used to serve as the International Development Officer working with international consumer electronics companies. He has a dual bachelors degree in physics and astronomy from Yale and is on the board of 2U, an education technology company. Todd Yellin is the Vice President of Product. His role is to change how people find cntent to stream on their TV's and other devices. His responsibility is largely manage large amounts of information from data and consistently manage user-friendly interfaces across devices. He supervises social media messaging to influence member aquisition. He has written a film and worked on a documentary filming political unrest. He has a Bachelors from UPenn and an MFA from USC. In 2016, he was mentioned in a case study done on Netflix and how user data is collected. He was forthcoming in how Netflix gathered data and made it known that Netflix tracks data whether on playback or abandonment. Amy Reinhard is the Vice President of Studio Operations. She is in charge of leading global studio liscensing not only for films and TV, but also language acquisitions all over the world. She also oversees other areas of production, such as production facilities, consumer products and creatives, casting, IP management, and music development. She has a bachelors and masters degree from Harvard.

overview.name: Policy Management
overview.description: Maria Ferreras, from Puerto Rico, is the Global Head of Business Development and manages all of Netflix's partnerships in the Amsterdam office. Her previous focus was in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa and she has other experience globally as well. She worked a similar job at Google for 10 years where she managed content for direct partnerships. Ferreras is experienced in high level management positions. An article on Spain News describes her position as "develop[ing] agreements with third parties that increase Netflix's presence to reach more consumers, and in the process facilitate their access and payment method". Dean Garfield is the Vice President of Public Policy. He works to make a social, worldy change in his daily work by forming global policies. He has served a number of numerous roles at Netflix. Trump and Obama both designated him to the President's Trade Advisory Council and recently two more government comittees. He attended NYU and Princeton and won two scholarly titles. He currently works in the Amsterdam office.

He currently works in the Amsterdam office.

overview.name: Legal Affairs
overview.description: Byrony Gagan is the Vice President of Business and Legal Affairs and supervises content production and distribution, escpecially everything created in house at Netflix. She has previous experience in content liscensing and was previously an associate and clerk for two notable law firms. She went to Georgetown and progressed onto Standford Law School. In an interview she did on Georgetown Alumi's Students in Media and Entertainment Industries site, she says that her favorite thing about working at Netlix is how her role is constantly changing and evolving. David Hyman is the Chief Legal Officer and is responsible for all legal matters at Netlix. He doubles as Secretary, and was previously a General Council of Webvan. He practiced law in San Francisco and Washington, D.C. after earning a degree from the University of Virginia. In an interview, he says he has high hopes for the company and where their original content will take them.

overview.name: Finance and Operations
overview.description: Spencer Neumann is the Chief Financial Officer as of 2019 after leaving the position of CEO at Activision Blizzard. He worked at Disney as CFO and executive VP of Global Guest Experience. He worked at two private equity firms and worked at ABC Network. He has a bachelors and MBA from Harvard and is on the board of directors at Make a Wish. An LA Times article recounts how Activision Blizzard sued Netflix for taking Neumann from them. He broke his contract early, not being the first executive to be hired by Netflix in a poaching manner.

overview.name: Data and Engineering
overview.description: Caitlin Smallwood is the Vice President of Data and Insights. Mark White is the Vice President of Engineering. She has pioneered new data science functions since her start at Netflix in 2010. Currently she is working on data engineering, statistical and consumer research and mathematical models to optimize Netflix's software and overall user experience. She has a bachelors from the College of WIlliam and Mary and a masters from Stanford. At a Spark + AI Summit in 2019, she explains how some of the algorithms work. For example, she says that Netflix's software creates interest clusters, but since peoples movie preferences are so intricate and diverse, they often show a "Based on watching this, you might like this movie" option. This in turn helps Netlix learn more deeply of our preferences. She is from Virginia and currently works in Palo Alto. Mark White is the Vice President of Engineering as of this year. The teams he oversees do content creation, personalization algorithms, Netflix API and E-commerce systems. He worked as an engineering manager at PayPal and Skype. He is from Chicago and attended the University of Kansas.

overview.name: Subscriber growth due to COVID-19
overview.description: Netflix remains the largest subscriptionvideo-on-demand (SVOD) platform with an expected figure of 67.70 million paying subscribers by the year 2025. The biggest expansion of Netflix from January to March came from Europe, where it added a record 4.4 million new customers.

overview.name: Subscriber growth due to COVID-19
overview.description: Netflix remains the largest subscriptionvideo-on-demand (SVOD) platform with an expected figure of 67.70 million paying subscribers by the year 2025. The biggest expansion of Netflix from January to March came from Europe, where it added a record 4.4 million new customers.

overview.name: Netflix users by region age 16-64
overview.description: The statistic shows the share of internet users who use Netflix worldwide as of the second quarter of 2017, by region. According to the source, 61 percent of internet users in North America used Netflix in the last month as of the second quarter of 2017.

overview.description: In 2019, Brazil is expected to have the largest Netflix viewer base - 28.7 million people, followed by Mexico with 19.3 million and Argentina with 5.9 million viewers.

overview.name: Netflix tops subscriber mark because of Brigerton show
overview.description: Tight global coronavirus restrictions helped Netflix to beat expectations on Wall Street as its global audience surpassed 200 million for the first time. Bridgerton had attracted new viewers in the final quarter. The company, which has 203.66 million subscribers, expects to attract six million more in the first three months of this year.

overview.name: Produced Content Assets
overview.description: The content Netflix has changes with each different country it is in. The text focusses how Netflix was dispersed in Latin America. Japan surprizingly has the biggest selection of Netflix titles, I'm most guessing due to anime. Other big distributers like Disney and Warner Bros have pulled their content off Netflix in order to promote their own streaming platforms.

overview.name: Regional Rev per customer
overview.description: Customers in America and Canada gave Netflix $12.57 more per subscription compared to 2019. Profit off of customers is much lower in other countries such as Latin America.

overview.name: Global Revenue
overview.description: Most of Netflix's revenue comes from America, Canada, Europe, and the Middle East. Lation America and Asia Pacific offer Netflix the least value. 55% of members and 50% of the revenues are international.

overview.name: Revenue Competition
overview.description: A nigerian media giant producing Afro content is expanding to America and globally with the help of their newly aquired company, KeduTV LLC. This company is predicted to make 10.5bil in revenue by 2023.

overview.name: Revenue from India
overview.description: The number of Netflix consumers in India has doubled in the last year due to Netflix increasing the number of Indian titles on the platform along with 100 new employees in India.

overview.name: Covid on Revenue
overview.description: Since so many people were watching Netflix during Covid, the servers got overloaded. Netflix needed to decrease the streaming quality of their platform

overview.name: Poland and Netflix
overview.description: Poland wants to decrease the number of people in its population from video games and television so they are making it 1.5% more expensive to have a Netflix subscription each month. Other countries such as Austrailia are charging taxes on media as well.
